comments.commentBody: @Margo: It's very easy for you to be so pious from your comfortable, safe American home- and to advocate an agenda that, in effect, calls for the deaths of more Israelis and even more Palestinians. If it's okay for the Israelis to occupy the West Bank and Gaza (which is, indeed, still in a state of occupation considering that no one gets in or out without Israeli permission) then I suppose you would have had no objection had Israeli troops marched into Egypt, Jordan and Syria at the conclusion of the Six-Day War and established settlements in those countries as well. As for Israel's "favorable deal," it would have chopped the Palestinian nation into a dozen mall non-contiguous pieces. Fatah had no choice other than to reject it.

Yes, and getting a medallion as little guy in NYC is virtually impossible because they are so expensive. But with the advent of Uber, medallions hve fallen in value and medallion kings are in financial trouble.  But that does not make any of this right.  Basically people are enslaved if driving is their sole or main source of income.  They drive an inordinate number of hours making travel unsafe for them and their passengers.

If Uber evil for classifying drivers as independent contractors, so are most traditional taxi companies.   Some quick googling indicates that between 75-85% of traditional taxi drivers are classified as independent contractors.

> The entrepreneur says, "this is brilliant, lets monetize it." The government says, "this is brilliant, lets kill it."

Great observation. All the arguments about healthcare, insurance, etc should be directed toward the government, not employers. Government should provide these essential services so that both employees and employers can be more nimble and be protected. Asking employers to provide these services simply makes our corporations less competitive. Let's have a smarter government that actually helps its citizens and employers, rather than burying its head in the 19th century labor laws.
A new technology comes along. The entrepreneur says, "this is brilliant, lets monetize it." The government says, "this is brilliant, lets kill it."
winemaster... yes it's a far better team....it's actually Oakland...where Golden State has played since the early 70's....
GSW are an Oakland team.

It plays in Oakland , where the facility is located, but it is a San Francisco Team.   But   since it is in the Bay Area    Golden State is a far better name and they should delete the word Warriors. Because   CA never had any kind of warriors , unless we include  some Native Indian Tribes.

No big deal, it is just another basketball season's end and in the middle June.  These players make enough money , what is just another title. James  what ever is his last name is indeed a good player and a good leader of his team. Bu then no body can win all the time. These finals  proved beyond a doubt that GSW, that folks is a San Francisco team, is far far better then  the Cleveland Cavs.  Plus Steve Kerr  is the best coach, who made the right choice rather then be a coach for the Nicks.
The last point guard similarly worshiped was Jeremy Lin.

Check the season statistics.   Curry had a lot of turnovers with his ball handling technique.   The Cavaliers used pressure to their advantage early on, but then their legs gave out.   Dellavedova was hospitalized overnight for cramps.

Just recently, I noticed that a highly innovative player, this year's MVP, Stephen Curry, approaches handling the ball in a rapidly shifting and unpredictable manner that brought to mind my extreme using of spatial panning. Curry unleashes a whirlwind of multi-directional gestures that may be likened to Tandava, Shiva's Dance of Destruction, and that is certainly what he accomplishes in terms of the opposing team's defense! Curry’s dizzying flurry of movements culminate with an unearthly smooth and high-arched shot that often gives the impression of only moving the net by virtue of the rush of air passing through without actually touching. In this context, the gracefulness of Curry's shot may be compared to Shiva's Laysa, a gentle form of dance.

Your statements about James's shooting couldn't be more wrong.  Check his regular season shooting percentages for the last five years.  When you've got no legs because you're constantly playing exhausted your shot suffers.  Whatever you think about Jordan, LeBron is clearly a superstar.  Moreover, he is known as one of the hardest workers in the NBA.  When writing about a player of his stature, rookie mistakes are kindof offensive.

Exactly right, Michjas.

In man of those shot by LeBron, he would have passed to Kyrie and Kevin. Instead of being double teamed, instead of wearing out his legs.

In many situations, LBJ would not even had the ball. Kyrie would have.

In game 1, won in overtime by the Warriors, a healthy Kyrie twice blocked Curry's shot.

Overwrought. This was not some seismic shift in the way the game is played, there have been run and gun offenses for decades. The difference was talent on both ends. No run and gun team has ever had this many shooters that could also play defense. Nearly every Warrior on the floor was a legitimate 3-point threat, with Curry and Thompson being Reggie Miller-like 3 ballers. Nearly every Warrior on the floor could also defend. Remember the previous series for the Cavs? JR Smith could beat his man at will—Korver (great shooter, no defense). Smith killed Atlanta, going off in several games and tipping the series. Covered by an athletic defender, Smith had no room to operate whatsoever in this series, and was a nonfactor. Same with Dellavedova, no threat at all. It’s a game of matchups, and the depleted Cavs roster was woefully undermanned.

Also, for all the “Best on the Planet” hype, LeBron’s outside game was suspect. He’s not commanding the same respect from midrange and beyond, laying a lot of bricks, defenders can get away with sagging a bit, take away his explosive first step. So more and more, his drives become contact-heavy bull rushes and flings, rather than getting separation and making a controlled finish. Remember Jordan’s deadly midrange game as he got older. Jab step and rise up.

"What A Symphony It Was" --- you mean the players got locked out, salaries were cut, management blamed the players' greed for budgetary problems while deliberately scaling back on fundraising, and anybody who cared was derided as a rich, elitist snob?

Oh, sorry. That's the other kind of symphony. Never mind.

Yes, and the way the civil and criminal courts run even the JUDGES engaged in corruption and judicial criminal frauds as judicial officers of the courts along with deprivations of rights to due process, civil rights violations -ex-parte communications - These are the real criminals along with the dirty politicians

Having worked in Village Government, my fantasy is that the State has to abide by the rules local Government does.  One law per bill, publishing of that bill, debate of that bill, and votes for each up or down.  Strict conflict of interest rules, and you have to balance budgets.  Really, if they lived by the rules they give us "lower" government bodies, it would all be a lot more transparent.  Instead, the State of NY resembles the Politboro in the late Soviet era...that isn't a slam, but a fact....read how both work (ed)
Says the Supervisor who the court held to illegally prevent a church from moving to Greenburgh and who destroyed documents.

New York State desperately needs a constitutional convention. We need to reinvent the way government in NYS runs.
PAUL FEINER
Greenburgh Town Supervisor
I'd like to give away about half of mine.

What a fiasco on so many levels.  Cuomo said he created 500,000 jobs, but there is no data at Dept. of Labors office showing who, what or where?  Forget 3 men in a room...it's Larry, Curly and Moe running each state agency. Just match Commissioner to donations to Cuomo, as can be seen by the hiring of Howard Zemsky. There is so much turnover on the 2nd floor no wonder nothing gets done.

@A. Stanton: Fatah would be willing to sit down and negotiate if Netanyahu would freeze the building of settlements and if he'd stop insisting that Fatah engage Hamas in internecine warfare over those damned rockets over which Fatah has no control.  Inasmuch as Israel has not even recognized the Palestinians' right to an independent homeland, why should Fatah now recognize the Jewish state?  On the other hand, you're right about Willie Mays- he was better than Duke Snider and better even than Mickey Mantle.
Great, if you've got $5k for a one bedroom. The rest of us need strong rent stabilization legislation and affordable housing.

As many readers have pointed out, parts of our country have actually experienced substantial housing inflation.

The secret of keeping home prices down, in areas such as New York City and San Francisco, is no secret - all you have to do, is throttle down the large numbers of immigrants hitting our shores at these points.

In urban areas, where there are no empty lots to be had, immigration guarantees housing inflation.

Increased density solutions, as exemplified by the De Blasio plan that promotes "legalized dwelling" in illegal basement apartments, represent a bizarre rollback to the squalid urban conditions of the 19th century - totally unacceptable in the modern world.

The simple solution is to recognize that while we are short on land, potable water, and fuel, we are not short on people - the unemployment numbers prove this every month; even as total employment goes up, the rate of unemployment does not subside.

Decent and affordable housing can not be "crowd sourced"; for densely populated areas, immigration is a problem, not a solution.
@Sharon101: "Payback?"  Who are you, Al Capone? Why not unleash the Mossad on Germany or Russia or Spain or Egypt?  Or all of the above?

I was at Oracle for the watch party. The crowd was 50% African American. Your video interviewed 6 people none were African American.   In addition, the Warriors were the champions!  You don't say this for 3 paragraphs.  This article clearly shows bias of your readers: east coast and white.
Thank you for your terrific analysis, a pleasure to read.

This article, and the statements by King, show that he's a fraud (most likely put up to this by right wing Obama haters) and why this case had no legal standing to begin with. However, with the most reactionary, activist, court since the Taney Court, he's probably right- he does have a good chance of winning.

64? One year away from Medicare, even if he wasn't eligible for Vet's benefits. I'm 64 too, and unlike this screwball, I'd love to see all Americans, regardless of age, have a path to paid health insurance like he and I will.

“I listen to everybody bitch and moan and cry about Obamacare,”

Yeah, right, everybody.

SCOTUS’s rulings in President Obama’s term have been almost predictably against policies he advocates, especially as they relate to far less well-off Americans.
Republicans and their strata draw comfort knowing what they cannot achieve legislatively; their seemingly Court consorts will deliver.
The courts have always considered politics in their rulings, but this SCOTUS appears more like an arm of 'Special Interest' than that of US Constitutional imperatives.
So then, Hon. Mr. Chief Justice,were is the justice for all; if it cannot be hoped for in the halls of an increasingly appearing lowly Court on high? I think that our justice systems is not so much blind as its stewards practices have become myopic and risk to American posterity.

This man is a damned fool, a willing tool of the wealthy right wingers who conspired to destroy Obamacare. He believes whatever the lawyers tell him. But there is no Plan B, unless he thinks buying inferior, limited-coverage polices across state lines from Mississippi or some other hellhole, or limitations on malpractice suits, will accomplish everything Obamacare has.

But, doesn't that typify the majority of the Republican party? What ever happened to the Republican party of Lincoln? These people care about themselves and their bank accounts and no one or nothing else.
What a thoughtless and selfish man.
Complete rubbish!
Wow, such animosity for fellow working Americans. Just how do you know what the rest of us do not that the TPP provides for "more level trade and investment rules". Do you have a secret copy.

@schrodinger "Oh sure, let's make the American middle class compete on a level playing field with Vietnamese peasants earning $1 a day."

Why not? If Vietnam is following the level-playing-field set of rules, be they WTO or bilateral-agreement or TPP, what is unfair about competition?

Do you think American, Japanese and European workers somehow have a God given right to be, in perpetuity, paid more than others workers freely doing the same job with the same quality? Why?

It is an unsustainable model. Extorted union ages worked in 1945 when the US had 1/2 the world GDP and the other industrial powers were in ruins. It work somewhat in the 60s and 70s when the US-reconstructed economies of Japan and Europe plus hours were 3/4 of world GDP.

But it is destined to fail. Global wages, specially for unskilled and semi-skilled labor will eventually level off globally. You can't charge 20 times as much for oil or bricks or steel in the US than in Vietnam. And neither can you indefinitely charge 20 times more for an unskilled worker without huge imbalances like people migration and jobs migration.

Too many words, when we know the reason why the Democrats are boycotting fast track.

Unions own the Democrats and unions will do anything to avoid having to compete on a level playing field. They are determined to keep their extorted perks the only way they know how - preventing competition. That mean opposing charter schools, opposing right to work, opposing more level trade and investment rules.

They are willing to cede Asia to Chinese control to protect a couple of million of privileged unionized jobs.

It is that simple.

They are doing so because of politics and the rough 2016 map for them. It's funny because the right wingers who want to extend subsidies through 2017 are running in swing states and supported the repeal the ACA. I hope Obama vetoes this bill if it does get to his desk. The GOP are the party that will be responsible for taking health care away from MILLIONS of Americans.

Woof,

Thanks for the SecDef view, but I just don't get why we are excluding China from the TPP. It gives the strong impression that they are the lead in one trade block and we are in the other. That is not very rational. We do not need to contain China, that want work. China can be and probably is one of our best markets. Building tensions with trade is bad policy. It simply will not pay in the long run.

As China builds an economy based on its domestic consumption vs exports, they will be a great market and provide the US and others with a higher standard of living.

Developing Trade Agreements to establish a geopolitical military power is not wise.

Trust me we need to concentrate bringing China into the global warming fight. The TPP would be a great vehicle for doing it.

Cheri, I honestly feel for you. The only enlightenment I can offer is that there are several, maybe three people involved in bringing this case. If you read down, you will see that after that I am lost. Hang in there and all my best to you and everyone worried over this.
